revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title=Affordable Space Adventures |image= Affordable Space Adventures logo.png |developer = [[KnapNok Games]]
[[Nicklas Nygren]] |publisher = KnapNok Games |engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] |platforms = [[Wii U]] |released = April 9, 2015 |genre = [[Puzzle game|Puzzle]], [[Adventure game|adventure]] |modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] }} '''''Affordable Space Adventures''''' is a [[puzzle game|puzzle]] [[adventure game|adventure]] game developed and published by [[KnapNok Games]] in collaboration with [[Nifflas|Nifflas' Games]]. The game was released for the [[Wii U]] via the [[Nintendo eShop]] download service on April 9, 2015. The game's main gameplay feature is its unique use of the Wii U Gamepad to control a spaceship by using the controls shown on the touch-screen. ==Plot== In ''Affordable Space Adventures'', the player takes on the role of a customer who has purchased an "Affordable Space Adventure" from the company UExplore. The game begins with a video that describes a newly discovered planet ready to be explored by the company's customers, even promising to allow them to take ownership of and colonize their own individual piece of the planet. It introduces the customer to the Small Craft, their own personal vehicle with which they will explore the planet's surface, and describes the process by which the customer is to be placed on and retrieved from the planet. All along the way, UExplore extols the virtues of its perfect safety record - more specifically that they have had no "recorded" accidents in two decades. An unexplained incident occurs between the end of the video and the start of the game, where the player awakens to discover that the mother ship has crashed in a hostile extraterrestrial environment, leaving the player no choice but to explore his/her environment. Along the way, the Small Craft slowly repairs its systems, bringing new functionality online at key points. The player is also informed of alien "artifacts" that he/she must avoid disturbing at all costs, under penalty of fines. The player searches for a functional distress beacon that will allow him/her to request emergency extraction. However, the beacons that the player finds are damaged or otherwise non-functional, forcing further exploration. As the game proceeds, more promotional videos emerge from UExplore talking about how safe their program is - so much so, in fact, that the company's safety director was given an extended vacation. The player eventually comes upon an alien installation that has the ability to alter reality in short bursts. The Small Craft penetrates this installation's defenses and causes a massive explosion, resulting in the ship being sent back to the surface, heavily damaged. The player sets off again in search of another beacon. The Small Craft begins to fall apart, system after system failing and shutting down until only the most basic systems are left online. The player finally discovers a working beacon in the middle of a harsh blizzard that, despite generating maximum heat, threatens to freeze the Small Craft solid. After filling out a casual survey form, the beacon puts the player in stasis to await extraction. In a short scene after the credits, the player's survey form (including their [[Miiverse]] drawing if provided) emerges from an interstellar fax machine in the long-unoccupied office of UExplore's safety director, ending up on the floor with numerous other calls for help. ==Gameplay== The goal of ''Affordable Space Adventures'' is to explore the environment of Spectaculon and find a means to request evacuation from the planet. The player controls the Small Craft, a small flying ship that can move around in two dimensions and interact with its environment in limited ways. A variety of systems are available to the player by pressing buttons on the [[Wii U GamePad|gamepad and its touch screen]], including a flashlight and scanner, two different engines, a mass generator, an anti-gravity device, several landing gears, etc. The gamepad thus functions as the Small Craft's control panel, both allowing the player to control the ship and tweak its systems, and conveying important information about the environment and the ship's functions. The game is broken up into a series of levels consisting of puzzles of increasing complexity. Some puzzles require the player to open doors by pressing buttons hidden among the environment, while others are only passable by blocking lasers with objects found in the environment, or by sneaking past alien artifacts that will attack the Small Craft if it generates too much noise, heat or electrical radiation (a set of output meters indicate what each artifact's thresholds are after they are scanned). Up to two additional players may join the game at the beginning using [[Wii Remote]]s or [[Wii Classic Controller]]s, taking over movement and scanning functions. The game also features two difficulty levels, Tourist and Technical, and a separate [[Downloadable content|DLC]] pack, the Origin Story, consists of much harder levels. == Origin Story DLC == In November 12 [[KnapNok Games]] released a free update for the game which fixed several bugs in the game as well as added five new levels in a separate mode named "Origin Story".{{Cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2015/11/free_origin_story_and_remaster_update_coming_to_affordable_space_adventures|title=Free Origin Story and 'Remaster' Update Coming to Affordable Space Adventures|last=Life|first=Nintendo|date=2015-11-09|website=Nintendo Life|access-date=2016-06-09}} The new levels were meant for experienced players who have already finished the game and were looking for a new challenge, though once the update has been installed, players can choose to play those new levels anytime. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | width = 23em; clear: none | MC = 81/100{{cite news|title=''Affordable Space Adventures'' Reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii-u/affordable-space-adventures|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=2015-08-19}} | Destruct = 9/10{{cite web| last = Hancock| first = Patrick| title = "Affordable Space Adventures" Review| work = Destructoid| date=2015-04-04|accessdate = 2015-08-19| url = http://www.destructoid.com/review-affordable-space-adventures-289938.phtml}} | IGN = 8.5/10{{cite web| last = Rodriguez| first = Jose A.| title = Affordable Space Adventures - Analisis| work = IGN| date=2015-04-14|accessdate = 2016-06-09| url = http://es.ign.com/affordable-space-adventures-wii-u/92597/review/affordable-space-adventures-analisis-para-wii-u}} | GSpot = 8/10{{cite web| last = Venter| first = Jason| title = "Affordable Space Adventures" Review| work = GSpot| date=2015-04-21|accessdate = 2015-08-19| url = http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/affordable-space-adventures-review/1900-6416111/}} | GI = 8/10{{cite web| last = Hilliard| first = Kyle| title = Interstellar Micromanagement - Affordable Space Adventures| work = GI| date=2015-04-08|accessdate = 2015-08-19| url = http://www.gameinformer.com/games/affordable_space_adventures/b/wii_u/archive/2015/04/08/affordable-space-adventures-game-informer-review.aspx/}} | NLife = 8/10{{cite web| last = Whitehead| first = Thomas| title = Affordable Space Adventures Review| work = NLife| date=2015-04-06|accessdate = 2015-04-06| url = http://www.nintendolife.com/reviews/wiiu-eshop/affordable_space_adventures}} }} Upon launch, the game received generally positive reviews, with most media outlets calling out the integration of the Wii U's unique features. Patrick Hancock of ''[[Destructoid]]'' mentioned that "GamePad and [[Miiverse]] integration are perfect, and I'm not sure that sentence has been made before"{{cite web|last1=Hancock|first1=Patrick|title=Review: Affordable Space Adventures|url=https://www.destructoid.com/review-affordable-space-adventures-289938.phtml|website=Destructoid}} and Thomas Whitehead of ''[[Nintendo Life]]'' claiming it to be "one of the eShop's top-tier games".{{cite web|last1=Whitehead|first1=Thomas|title=Review: Affordable Space Adventures (Wii U eShop)|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/reviews/wiiu-eshop/affordable_space_adventures|website=Nintendo Life|date=6 April 2015}} Another aspect that got the attention of the media was the optional co-op multiplayer mode, which Andy Robertson of ''[[Forbes]]'' compared to live action ''[[Star Trek]]''.{{cite web|last1=Robertson|first1=Andy|title='Affordable Space Adventures' Is Live Action 'Star Trek'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andyrobertson/2015/04/28/affordable-space-adventures-review/#687f01e5c41c|website=Forbes}} Affordable Space Adventures received several awards. Prior to launch, the game already received the "Best of [[PAX East 2015]]" award by ''Destructoid'',{{Cite web|url=https://www.destructoid.com/here-are-destructoid-s-top-10-games-from-pax-east-2015-288751.phtml|title=Here are Destructoid's Top 10 games from PAX East 2015|website=Destructoid|access-date=2016-06-09}} and continued to receive subsequent awards after the game's launch. At the Danish SpilPrisen Awards in 2016, granted by the [[Danish Film Institute]], the game received awards for "Game of the Year", "Best Technical Achievement" and "Best Game Design",{{Cite web|url=http://www.dfi.dk/nyheder/filmupdate/2016/april/vinderne-af-spilprisen-2016.aspx|title=Vinderne af Spilprisen 2016|website=www.dfi.dk|access-date=2016-06-09}} while at the Nordic Game Awards 2016 the game won the "Best Game Design" award.{{Cite web|url=https://nordicgame.com/nordic-game-awards-2016-winners-revealed/|title=Nordic Game Awards • Nordic Game 2016|date=2015-05-05|website=Nordic Game 2017|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-09}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://affordablespaceadventures.com/}} *[http://knapnokgames.com/ Developer website] {{portal bar|Video games|2010s}} [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Science fiction video games]] [[Category:Unity (game engine) games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Denmark]] [[Category:Wii U games]] [[Category:Wii U-only games]] [[Category:Wii U eShop games]]

page.title: Alice Through the Looking Glass (1987 film)

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox film | name = Alice Through the Looking Glass | image = | image size = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Andrea Bresciani]]
[[Richard Slapczynski]] | producer = [[Jameson Brewer]] | writer = Jameson Brewer | screenplay = | story = | based on = {{based on|[[Through the Looking-Glass]]|[[Lewis Carroll]]}} | narrator = | starring = [[Janet Waldo]]
[[Mr. T]]
[[Jonathan Winters]]
[[Phyllis Diller]]
[[George Gobel]]
[[Alan Young]]
[[Clive Revill]]
[[Townsend Coleman]] | music = [[Todd Hayen]] | cinematography = | editing = | studio = [[Burbank Films Australia]]
[[Jambre Productions]] | distributor = [[Purple Cow Productions]] | released = | runtime = 73 minutes | country = [[Australia]]
[[Italy]]
[[United States]]
[[Poland]] | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Alice Through the Looking Glass''''' is a 1987 Australian-Italian animated film nominally based on the novel ''[[Through the Looking-Glass]]'' by [[Lewis Carroll]]. It was directed by [[Andrea Bresciani]] and [[Richard Slapczynski]] from a screenplay by [[Jameson Brewer]]. The movie starts off with a bored Alice trapped in her house by a snow storm. The film's voice cast includes [[Janet Waldo]] as Alice, [[Mr. T.]] as the [[Jabberwock]], [[Phyllis Diller]] as the White Queen, [[Jonathan Winters]] as Tweedledum and Tweedledee, and [[Alan Young]] as the White Knight. Much of the film consists of Alice and a [[jester]] named Tom Fool ([[Townsend Coleman]]) journeying through some of the incidents of the novel, while ultimately, the film is more about Alice finding an imaginary friend in Tom Fool than the novel's themes of logic, illogic, and reversal. The film also throws in [[Heffalumps]], rock-throwing [[cavemen]], [[Ed Sullivan]], [[The Marx Brothers]] ([[Hal Rayle]]) and [[Humpty Dumpty]] ([[George Gobel]]). There is also a man made entirely out of newspaper, a talking horse and a talking goat. When Alice wakes up, her father plays a game of chess with her, which her dream journey was based on, walking from square to square on a large chessboard. ==External links== * {{Imdb title|0101294|Alice Through the Looking Glass (1987)}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|1162553-alice_through_the_looking_glass|Alice Through the Looking Glass (1987)}} * {{Tv.com movie|alice-through-the-looking-glass-2013|Alice Through the Looking Glass (1987)}} * {{AllMovie title|1485|Alice Through the Looking Glass (1987)}} {{Alice}} {{Burbank}} [[Category:1987 films]] [[Category:1987 animated films]] [[Category:1980s fantasy films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Animated films based on Alice in Wonderland]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of The Marx Brothers]] {{1980s-Australia-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = America's Incredible Pizza Company | logo = America's IPC logo.png | logo_size = 250px | type = | foundation = {{start date and age|2002}} | location = [[Springfield, Missouri|Springfield]], [[Missouri]], U.S. | area_served = United States, Mexico | key_people = Rick Barsness Founder & CEO,
Cheryl Barsness Founder | industry = Restaurants | products = [[Pizza]] | revenue = $64.1 million | num_employees = 1,200 | homepage = {{URL|http://www.incrediblepizza.com/}} |}} '''America's Incredible Pizza Company''' ('''AIPC''') is an [[United States|American]] [[restaurant chain]] based in [[Springfield, Missouri|Springfield]], [[Missouri]]. The restaurants are [[pizza]] [[buffet]]s and [[Family Entertainment Center|entertainment center]]s. The first restaurant opened in Springfield in 2002.{{cite news|first=Matt |last=Olberding |title=Pizza places planned for Omaha, Lincoln |url=http://www.journalstar.com/articles/2005/09/17/business/doc432b2bcc572ad288339319.txt |work=[[Lincoln Journal Star]] |date=17 September 2005 |accessdate=2008-11-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPFp0xl?url=http://www.journalstar.com/articles/2005/09/17/business/doc432b2bcc572ad288339319.txt |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|first=Scott |last=Cherry |title=Incredible Pizza Company delivers with loads of fun and good, filling food |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/common/printerfriendlystory.aspx?articleID=070406_8_S17_hIncr25141 |work=[[Tulsa World]] |date=6 April 2007 |accessdate=2008-11-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPIbkey?url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/common/printerfriendlystory.aspx?articleID=070406_8_S17_hIncr25141 |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} The company has 1,200 employees, and a revenue of $64.1 million.{{cite journal|url=http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/company-profile.html?id=200804560 |title=The Fastest Growing Private Companies in America: America's Incredible Pizza Company |accessdate=2014-08-27 |work=Inc. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPKNJ4M?url=http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/company-profile.html?id=200804560 |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==History== America's Incredible Pizza Company, headquartered in Springfield, Missouri, is owned by Rick and Cheryl Barsness. The couple entered the pizza business with a single restaurant in [[Victoria, Texas]] and by 1975, owned 11 franchises of [[Gatti's Pizza]]. AIPC grew out of an idea from its founder, Rick Barsness. When Barsness was a [[ice hockey|hockey]] player in high school, his team reached the state championships, but his father never attended a game. His father's absence nurtured a boyhood dream of a place where families could eat and have fun together. This was the type of place Barsness wished he could have spent time with his father.Whiteman (2006){{rp|2}} In 2003, years of legal battles came to an end when Rick Barsness agreed to pay Gatti's a $1 million [[settlement (litigation)|settlement]].{{cite news|first=Zeke |last=MacCormack |title=Pizza chain settles suit with former franchiser Mr. Gatti's will get $1 million and a bit of new venture's revenue. |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FCEC061655FBFAF&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |work=[[San Antonio Express-News]] |date=13 August 2003 |accessdate=2009-04-01 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5fhgE6wp4?url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FCEC061655FBFAF&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date%3AD&s_trackval=GooglePM |archivedate=2009-04-01 |deadurl=yes }} Mr. Gatti's had charged that Barsness had violated his franchise [[contract]] with them, and had taken [[trade secret]]s. In addition to the $1 million payout, Barsness also agreed to pay Mr. Gatti's Inc. 1% of IPC's net sales for the next 10 years.{{cite news|title=America's Incredible Pizza Company |url=http://vendors.pizzamarketplace.com/article.php?id=2676 |work=Pizza Marketplace |date=13 August 2003 |accessdate=2009-04-01 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5fhfq1Khb?url=http://vendors.pizzamarketplace.com/article.php?id=2676 |archivedate=2009-04-01 |deadurl=no |df= }} AIPC started franchising and established its corporate headquarters in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] in 2003. It moved the headquarters to Springfield, Missouri in 2009.{{cite web| url=http://incrediblepizza.com/corp/fun-for-kids/index.php| publisher=Incredible Pizza Company| title=Corporate Website: About Us| accessdate=2014-08-27}} AIPC restaurants have an average of 250 employees and it costs $5–9 million to start a restaurant.Whiteman (2006), p. 5. America's Incredible Pizza announced that its location at [[Lafayette Square Mall]] in Indianapolis would close March 19, 2012.{{cite news| url=http://www.theindychannel.com/news/lafayette-square-loses-major-tenant |title=Lafayette Square Loses Major Tenant| work=[[WRTV]] News |date=29 March 2012 |accessdate=2014-08-27}} ==Locations and format== As of October 2016, eight locations remain in operation in the United States, and three in Mexico.{{cite web|url=http://incrediblepizza.com/family-fun/ipc/ |title=Increcible Pizza Company |publisher=Incrediblepizza.com |date= |accessdate=2017-11-05}} In 2016, the mini golf at the Memphis, Tennessee branch was removed and replaced with a roller coaster. At the AIPC, the music and decorations have a 1950s theme. AIPC has a [[buffet]] style [[pizza]], [[pasta]], [[salad]], and [[dessert]] bar, with several seating areas for customers to eat.{{cite news|first=Charles |last=Williams |title=Incredible game room |url=http://www.stltoday.com/blogzone/house-o-fun/house-o-fun/2007/09/incredible-game-room/ |work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |date=21 September 2007 |accessdate=2008-11-27 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPWEG7E?url=http://www.stltoday.com/blogzone/house-o-fun/house-o-fun/2007/09/incredible-game-room/ |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} The restaurant has 30 types of pizza and an 80-item salad bar.{{cite web|url=http://www.cjmracing.com/race_rpts/2008/033108AIPC.html |title=TEAM CJM Racing and America’s Incredible Pizza Company |accessdate=2008-11-28 |work=[[CJM Racing]] |date=31 March 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPYMKeE?url=http://www.cjmracing.com/race_rpts/2008/033108AIPC.html |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} An AIPC restaurant has an average area of {{convert|65000|to|70000|sqft|m2}}.Whiteman (2006), p.4. The restaurant is [[smoke-free restaurant|smoke-free]] and [[alcoholic beverages|alcohol-free]].{{cite news|title=America's Incredible Pizza Company Opening Second DFW Metroplex Location, Creates Over 200 Jobs. |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/economy-economic-indicators/economic-indicators/10187523-1.html |work=[[Business Wire]] |date=7 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPajz75?url=http://www.allbusiness.com/economy-economic-indicators/economic-indicators/10187523-1.html |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} It has an [[Video arcade|arcade]], [[kart racing|go-karts]], [[Cue sports|billiards]], [[bowling]], and [[miniature golf]], among other activities.{{cite news|title=Family matters: incredible Pizza Company entertains the family market. |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-20397433_ITM |work=[[Chain Leader]] |date=1 February 2004 |accessdate=2008-11-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPdJekO?url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-20397433_ITM |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|first=Yvonne D. |last=Nelson |title=America's Incredible Pizza Company opens |url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2008/jan/17/focus-community-a-place-to-eat-and-play/ |work=[[The Commercial Appeal]] |date=17 January 2008 |accessdate=2014-08-27 |location=[[Memphis, Tennessee]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPfIffk?url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2008/jan/17/focus-community-a-place-to-eat-and-play/ |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==Incredible Pizza Company Foundation== In fall 2007, the Incredible Pizza Company founders, Rick and Cheryl Barsness, founded the Incredible Pizza Company Foundation (IPC Foundation) for the goal of donating to [[missionary|missionaries]] and [[orphanage]]s. On February 20, 2008, the IPC Foundation gave $24,000 to the [[Convoy of Hope]], a [[non-profit organization]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.convoyofhope.org/go/media/details/americas_incredible_pizza_company_joins_the_hopewalk |title=America's Incredible Pizza Company Joins the HopeWalk |accessdate=2008-11-26 |work=Convoy of Hope |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPDncli?url=http://www.convoyofhope.org/go/media/details/americas_incredible_pizza_company_joins_the_hopewalk |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} In September 2008, the IPCF donated $6,500 to Care to Learn, a fund managed by the Foundation for Springfield Public Schools.{{cite press release|title=Incredible Pizza Company Gives Back to Care to Learn |url=http://www.foundation4sps.org/news.htm |publisher=Foundation for Springfield Public Schools |date=18 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPhRA1L?url=http://www.foundation4sps.org/news.htm |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==NASCAR sponsorship== America's Incredible Pizza Company was the primary sponsor of number 11 [[CJM Racing]] in the [[NASCAR Nationwide Series]] in 2008 and 2009.{{cite news|title=Phoenix: Jason Keller race report |url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=285273&FS=NASCAR-NS |work=[[Motor Sport (magazine)|Motor Sport]] |date=11 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-27 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPjRrGX?url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=285273&FS=NASCAR-NS |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=yes }} On June 17, 2008, [[Jason Keller]], the driver of the Incredible Pizza-sponsored car, attended the opening of the 15th Incredible Pizza restaurant in [[Mesquite, Texas]].{{cite news|title=America's Incredible Pizza Announces Preview Event and Grand Opening Extravaganza |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/company-activities-management/company-structures-ownership/10531290-1.html |work=[[Business Wire]] |date=12 June 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-27 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPle30C?url=http://www.allbusiness.com/company-activities-management/company-structures-ownership/10531290-1.html |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} In 2008, first complete NASCAR season that the AIPC sponsored a racing team,{{cite news|title=Lagasse Jr to drive No. 11 for CJM Racing |url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=308063&FS=NASCAR-NS |work=Motor Sport |date=17 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-27 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPle30C?url=http://www.allbusiness.com/company-activities-management/company-structures-ownership/10531290-1.html |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} the team finished in 17th place.{{cite news|title=Season Finale Cut Short for Lagasse Jr. at Homestead |url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=314511 |work=Motor Sport |date=17 November 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-27 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPtPfK1?url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=314511 |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} In July 2008, CJM Racing and AIPC partnered with [[Joe Gibbs Racing]].{{cite news|title=CJM, Joe Gibbs Racing to form technical alliance |url=http://www.nascar.com/2008/news/headlines/bg/07/16/cjm.jgr.tech.alliance/index.html?eref=/rss/news/headlines/bg |work=[[NASCAR]] |date=16 July 2008 |accessdate=2009-11-29 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eBIzWVmb?url=http://www.nascar.com/2008/news/headlines/bg/07/16/cjm.jgr.tech.alliance/index.html?eref=%2Frss%2Fnews%2Fheadlines%2Fbg |archivedate=2009-01-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} The partnership between the two racing teams included the NASCAR driver [[Scott Lagasse Jr.]], who finished 13th in the No. 11 America's Incredible Pizza Company [[Chevrolet]] at [[Charlotte Motor Speedway]] in October 2008.{{cite news|title=Charlotte II: Scott Lagasse Jr race report |url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=311262&FS=NASCAR-NS |work=Motor Sport |date=10 October 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-29 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eBIZtUr7?url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=311262&FS=NASCAR-NS |archivedate=2009-01-29 |deadurl=yes }} The sponsorship ended in December 2009 when CJM Racing suspended operations.{{cite news| title=CJM Racing suspends operations| url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/nationwide/news/story?id=4755698| work=[[ESPN]]| date=18 December 2009| agency=[[Associated Press]]| accessdate=2014-08-27}} Keller provided the best run for the team, a third at [[Gateway Motorsports Park]] in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://racing-reference.info/drivdet/kelleja01/2008/B|title=Driver Jason Keller 2008 NASCAR Nationwide Series Results - Racing-Reference.info|website=racing-reference.info|access-date=2017-03-21}} ==Awards== In 2008, the America's Pizza Company was named a "Top Family Entertainment Center of the World" (TFEC) from the [[International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions]] (IAAPA),{{cite news|first=Marion |last=Hixon |title=Top FECs of the World awards went to Incredible Pizza Company and FUN CENTRAL Tecamac |url=http://www.iaapa.org/expos/attractions/ShowDaily08/wed/fecaward.asp |publisher=[[International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions]] |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-11-28 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chPv4am0?url=http://www.iaapa.org/expos/attractions/ShowDaily08/wed/fecaward.asp |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} which places it among one of the top five entertainment centers in the world.{{rp|6}} In 2008, AIPC was rated the 456th fastest growing company in the United States by the ''[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc]]'' 500.{{cite journal |url=http://www.incrediblepizza.com/documents/inc5000.pdf |title=Incredible Pizza joins the Inc. 5000 List at No. 456! |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-01-29 |publisher=America's Incredible Pizza Company |date=August 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eBKRvHC5?url=http://www.incrediblepizza.com/documents/inc5000.pdf |archivedate=2009-01-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} In the ''Inc.'' Top 100 Food & Beverage Companies, AIPC was rated number 12th, with a 693.1% growth.{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/lists/food-and-beverage-companies.html |title=Top 100 Food & Beverage Companies |accessdate=2009-01-29 |work=Inc |year=2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eBKP2ufs?url=http://www.inc.com/inc5000/2008/lists/food-and-beverage-companies.html |archivedate=2009-01-29 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==See also== * [[List of buffet restaurants]] * [[List of pizza chains of the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === *{{cite web|url=http://www.fdqmagazine.com/English/download.asp?Path=PDF/&File=Reprint12pg.pdf |title=Incredibly Ingenious |author=Pat Whiteman |accessdate=27 November 2008 |work=Food & Drink Quarterly |publisher=Positive Publications LLC |year=2006 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5chQO06jS?url=http://www.fdqmagazine.com/English/download.asp?Path=PDF%2F&File=Reprint12pg.pdf |archivedate=2008-11-29 |deadurl=yes }} ==External links== * [http://www.incrediblepizza.com/ Official website] * [http://incrediblepizza.com.mx/ Official website in Mexico] {{es icon}} {{pizza chains}} [[Category:Companies based in Springfield, Missouri]] [[Category:Economy of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Regional restaurant chains in the United States]] [[Category:Pizza chains of the United States]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 2003]] [[Category:Pizza franchises]] [[Category:Economy of the Midwestern United States]] [[Category:Video arcades]] [[Category:Buffet restaurants]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Missouri]]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = BIAF | image = | caption = | status = <!-- e.g. defunct, active, inactive ... --> | genre = [[Air show]] | dates = | frequency = Biennial | venue = Krumovo Airbase | location = | coordinates = | country = Bulgaria | established = 2007 | attendance = | activity = | organized = | website = }} '''BIAF''' ({{lang-bg|БИАФ}}) stands for Bulgarian International Air Festival; (''Български Международен Авиационен Фестивал / Balgarski Meschdunaroden Awiazionen Festiwal / Bulgarisches Internationales Luftfahrt Festival''). It is an international airshow held on [[Krumovo Airbase]], the military part of [[Plovdiv International Airport]]. It has been held every 2 years since 2007. The latest event was the 20th, 22nd, 27th, 28th, 29 September and the 2nd, 4th, 5th & 6 October 2013.
== BIAF 2011 == The theme of this year's show was '''100 Years of the Bulgarian Airforce'''
The show was divided into 3 section :
* The Past : Albatros, Kaproni, Dar-1, Laz-7 and Ме-109. * The Present : Galeb, Swiss Air Force PC 7 Team, BGR AF heute * The Future : JAS 39 Grippen, Eurofighter Typhoon and MiG-29OVT.
As usual several neighbouring and coalition countries took part in the show with their Airforces.
'''Dynamic display from:''' * [[Bulgarian Air Force]] – G 21, MiG 29A, PC9M, C 27J, Mi 17, Mi 24, Bell 206, AS 532AL, SU 25K * Swiss Air Force – PC 7 Team * Bulgarian Air Sport Ltd : Pitts – S2B LZ–AIR, Piper Dakota Turbo PA-28-201T * Bulgarian organization for flight education Ratan LZ-TSA – Sting 2000 RG; LZ-RSS – Sting 2000; LZ-HPM – Sting 2000 * Romanian Air Force – IAR 99 SOIM * [[German Air Force]] – EF Typhoon * Russia, RSK MiG – MiG 29M ОVT
'''Static display from:''' * Bulgarian Air Force – Mi 17, C-27J, PC 9M, SU 25 UBK, AS 532AL, MiG 21, MiG 29 UB * Bulgarian Association of Light Aviation * Bulgarian Aeromodeling Federation * АК Galeb, Serbia – Galeb * Flying club "Hawks", [[Romania]] * Swedish Air Force - Gripen JAS 39 * Romanian Air Force – C 27J * [[Italian Air Force]] – EF Typhoon * Greek Air Force – Т 6 * German Air Force – С160 Transall
== Gold Sponsors == with their own pavilion
* SAAB – Sweden * EADS / CASSIDIAN – Germany * Lockheed Martin – USA * Diehl Defence- Germany
== External links == {{Commons category|BIAF Airshow}} * [http://100.airshow-bg.com/welcome-welcome-en/?lang=en BIAF 2011 Offizielle Webseite]

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "American rock band" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|American rock band}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Bent Knee | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | genre = [[Art rock]], [[avant-garde music|avant-garde]], [[baroque pop]]{{cite web|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2016/04/bent-knee-announce-new-album-say-so-premiere-leak-water-songvideo-watch/|title=Bent Knee announce new album, Say So, premiere "Leak Water" song/video — watch|author=Michelle Geslani|publisher=Consequence of Sound|date=5 April 2016|accessdate=24 April 2016}} | years_active = 2009–present | label = [[Inside Out Music]], [[Sony Music]], [[Cuneiform Records]] | website = {{URL|http://www.bentkneemusic.com}} | current_members = Courtney Swain
Ben Levin
Jessica Kion
Gavin Wallace-Ailsworth
Chris Baum
Vince Welch }} '''Bent Knee''' is an American art rock band formed in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] in 2009. The band performs in multiple genres and draws from multiple influences, including [[pop music|pop]], [[industrial rock]], [[progressive rock]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/say-so-by-bent-knee-review-1464125585|title=‘Say So’ by Bent Knee Review|last=Fusilli|first=Jim|date=2016-05-24|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-07-25}} and [[avant-garde music|avant-garde]]. The band is known for unpredictable dynamic contrast and the wide vocal range of singer Courtney Swain.{{cite web|url=http://www.dprp.net/reviews/2016-010.php#bentknee|title=Bent Knee - Shiny Eyed Babies|first=Owen|last=Davies|publisher=DPRP|accessdate=3 September 2016}} Bent Knee has toured with [[The Dillinger Escape Plan]],{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/the-dillinger-escape-plan-announces-fall-u-s-tour/|title=THE DILLINGER ESCAPE PLAN Announces Fall U.S. Tour|date=2016-08-22|publisher=Blabbermouth}} [[Haken (band)|Haken]],{{cite web|url=https://www.hakenmusic.com/blog/post/us-tour-haken-leprous-bent-knee}} [[Leprous]],{{cite web|url=http://www.metalinjection.net/tour-dates/haken-leprous-bent-knee-to-tour-north-america-this-fall}} [[Thank You Scientist]],{{cite web|url=http://progreport.com/thank-scientist-tour-dates-bent-knee-announced/|title=Thank You Scientist tour dates with Bent Knee announced|date=2017-03-10|publisher=The Prog Report}} and [[Mike Keneally]].{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/mike.keneally/posts/10152156348416593|title=School For Robots and Bent Knee open for us tonight in Cambridge, MA.|author=Mike Keneally|publisher=Facebook|date=27 May 2014|accessdate=3 September 2016}} In 2016 they signed to [[Cuneiform Records]] for the release of their third album, ''Say So''.{{cite web|url=http://www.cuneiformrecords.com/bandshtml/bentknee.html|title=Cuneiform Records - Bent Knee|publisher=Cuneiform Records|date=2015-12-01}} In 2017, they inked a deal with [[Inside Out Music]] and released their fourth album, ''Land Animal''.{{cite web|url=http://www.insideoutmusic.com/artist.aspx?IdArtist=1947|title=Inside Out - Bent Knee|date=2017-04-19|publisher=Inside Out Music}} ==History== Bent Knee was formed at the [[Berklee College of Music]] in 2009, when guitarist Ben Levin and vocalist Courtney Swain began writing music together. The band self-released their first LP, ''Bent Knee'' in 2011, then self-released their follow up, ''Shiny Eyed Babies'' in 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2016/01/13/with-heady-buzz-and-new-bent-knee-bids-for-big-time/73c2nyNm4HgpSLfkCIoGiN/story.html|title=Bent Knee bids for the big time|first=Steve|last=Smith|date=2016-01-24|website=Boston Globe|accessdate=2016-07-25}} In late 2015, they were signed to [[Cuneiform Records]], an American independent record label,{{cite web|url=http://www.bentkneemusic.com/blog/2015/10/7/043czom7ydju9q06ovvg3b848647ql|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813074522/http://www.bentkneemusic.com/blog/2015/10/7/043czom7ydju9q06ovvg3b848647ql|title=Bent Knee Signs With Cuneiform Records|date=2015-12-05|archivedate=2016-08-13|website=Bent Knee Music|deadurl=yes|df=}} on which they released ''[[Say So]]'' in 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2016/05/18/bent-knee-favors-songcraft-over-showboating-new-album-say/FgiHVVxLQp9mPznDpxcqzN/story.html|title=Bent Knee favors songcraft over showboating on new album ‘Say So’|last=Smith|first=Steve|date=2016-05-19|website=The Boston Globe|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-25}} In April 2017, the band was signed by [[Inside Out Music]] for the release of their fourth album, ''Land Animal'', which was released June 23, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.insideoutmusic.com/newsdetailed.aspx?IdNews=18703|title=Bent Knee : Launched Music Video and Announce New Album "Land Animal" Out June 23 via INSIDEOUTMUSIC/SONY|website=Inside Out Music|date=20 April 2017|accessdate=29 April 2017}} An early mix of the song "These Hands" from the album ''Land Animal'' was featured as free content for [[Rock Band 4]] Rivals in March 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.harmonixmusic.com/blog/11-free-tracks-from-local-bands-headed-to-rock-band-rivals|title=11 free tracks from local bands headed to Rock Band Rivals|first=Nick|last=Gregoire|date=2017-02-28|website=Harmonix Blog|accessdate=2017-08-10}} == Members == *Courtney Swain – [[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]], [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]]s *Ben Levin – [[lead guitar]], [[Backing vocalist|backing vocals]] *Jessica Kion – [[Bass guitar|bass]], backing vocals *Gavin Wallace-Ailsworth – [[Drum kit|drums]] *Chris Baum – [[violin]], backing vocals *Vince Welch – [[Synthesizer|synth]]s, [[rhythm guitar]], sound design, [[Production (music)|production]] ==Discography== ;Studio albums * ''Bent Knee'' (2011) * ''Shiny Eyed Babies'' (2014) * ''[[Say So]]'' (2016) * ''Land Animal'' (2017) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 2009]] [[Category:Musical groups from Boston]] [[Category:Musical groups from Massachusetts]] {{music-stub}}

{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} '''''Bristow''''' is a British [[gag-a-day]] comic strip created by [[Frank Dickens]] about a buying clerk of that name. The series was in continuous publication in the ''[[Aberdeen Press & Journal]]'' in September 1961 until its last appearance in 2012. <ref name="Dickens"/> With over 10,000 strips made over the decades and running for over 51 years. ''Bristow'' is one of the longest running daily cartoon strips by a single author, according to [[Guinness World Records]].<ref name="Guinness"/> When looking at the character Bristow itself the series is even one year older than that, as Bristow debuted in Dickens' older series ''Oddbod'' in ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' in 1960. Due to his popularity he received his own [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] series soon afterwards.<ref name="Dickens"/> Dickens broke the original record held by [[Marc Sleen]], whose ''[[The Adventures of Nero]]'' was drawn for 45 years without any assistance.<ref name="lambiek.net">{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/s/sleen.htm |title=Marc Sleen (Biography) |accessdate=19 August 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422035032/https://www.lambiek.net/artists/s/sleen.htm |archivedate=22 April 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id%3Dcil7WbXg8BkC%26pg%3DPA102%26lpg%3DPA102%26dq%3Dguinness+book+of+records+marc+sleen%26source%3Dbl%26ots%3D9LPW61KHwW%26sig%3DpR0OR272m4Cqhj1iznUKKg61K44%26hl%3Dnl%26sa%3DX%26ved%3D0CCQQ6AEwATgKahUKEwiIpNyj4MvHAhWDtRoKHaaJDKo#v=onepage&q=guinness%20book%20of%20records%20marc%20sleen&f=false |title=Comics & Culture |page=102|accessdate=19 August 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180819201347/https://books.google.com/books?dq=guinness+book+of+records+marc+sleen&hl=nl&id=cil7WbXg8BkC&lpg=PA102&ots=9LPW61KHwW&pg=PA102&sa=X&sig=pR0OR272m4Cqhj1iznUKKg61K44&source=bl&ved=0CCQQ6AEwATgKahUKEwiIpNyj4MvHAhWDtRoKHaaJDKo#v=onepage&q=guinness%20book%20of%20records%20marc%20sleen&f=false |archivedate=19 August 2018 |df=dmy }}</ref> However, even Dickens' record has been broken in his turn by [[Jim Russell (cartoonist)|Jim Russell]], whose series ''[[The Potts]]'' ran for 62 years.<ref name="lambiek.net"/><ref name="Guinness">{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/longest-running-cartoon-strip-by-a-single-artist |title=Longest running cartoon strip by a single artist |accessdate=19 August 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160927183431/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/longest-running-cartoon-strip-by-a-single-artist |archivedate=27 September 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> <ref name="Dickens"/>
==Background== The cartoons follow the daily life of a buying clerk who works in the monolithic Chester-Perry building. He is a fantasist and has delusions of grandeur, wishing he were a brain surgeon and a writer. His epic tome ''Living Death in the Buying Department'' has yet to find a publisher, but he is not discouraged. He lives in a small bedsit in East Winchley and commutes to work by train, invariably arriving late. Bristow is surrounded by co-workers, Fudge (his overbearing manager), Jones, Hewitt, Dimkins, hapless typist Miss Sunman, master chef Gordon Blue, the Postboy and the ever-gossiping Mrs. Purdy the Tealady. Bristow has a crush on routine visitor Miss Pretty of "Kleenaphone". Another regular visitor is the pigeon who sits on a window ledge. During the winter, the bird travels to a warmer climate where she visits Bristow's counterpart, a black man in a white suit. Bristow invariably holidays at a beach resort known as Funboys Sur La Plage.
Frank Dickens is often credited for "inventing" a cartoon device whereby he wrote the words of the action next to the character, such as "flinch flinch", as he was unable to draw expressions well enough to fit in the comic-strip boxes.
==Syndication== The strip was widely syndicated in Great Britain and in Australia. It appeared in the Birmingham ''[[Birmingham Mail|Evening Mail]]'' and, between 1962 and 2001, appeared in the London ''[[Evening Standard]]'' newspaper. The ''[[Melbourne Age]]'' and ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' published the strip from the late 1960s. Since 1966 at least eleven ''Bristow'' books have been published in the UK, as well as editions in Australia.<ref name="Guter Bristow in Print"/> A number of collections were published in Italy with the captions translated.
==Radio adaptation== "Bristow" was made into a [[BBC Radio 4]] series<ref name="EpGuides Bristow"/> written by Dickens and starring both [[Michael Williams (actor)|Michael Williams]] as Bristow and [[Rodney Bewes]] as his colleague Jones.<ref name="The Independent April 1999"/> There were 14 half-hour episodes made from April 1999 to July 2000,<ref name="Evening Standard April 2001"/> with frequent repeats on [[BBC 7]].<ref name="UtterTrivia Bristow"/> (Radio 4 Extra).
==Stage adaptation==
In 1971 the strip was also adapted into a theatrical play. <ref name="Dickens">{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/d/dickens_frank.htm |title=Frank Dickens (Biography) |publisher=Lambiek|accessdate=19 August 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918014042/https://www.lambiek.net/artists/d/dickens_frank.htm |archivedate=18 September 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>

{{redirect|Pop Up (video game)|the phenomenon in 3D video games|Pop-up (video gaming)}} {{Infobox VG |title = Bumpy's Arcade Fantasy |image = |caption = |developer = [[Loriciels]] |publisher = |released = 1989 |genre = [[Platform game]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[ZX Spectrum]]
[[Amstrad CPC]]
[[Personal computer|PC]] |series = }} '''''Bumpy''''', also known as '''''Pop-Up''''' and '''''Cool-Ball''''', is a [[2D computer graphics|2D]] [[platform game|platforming]] [[video game]] created by [[Loriciels]]. It was released in 1989 for [[ZX Spectrum]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Atari ST]], [[MSX]] and [[DOS]]http://www.mobygames.com/game/bumpy. A remake of the game was created in 1992 with the name '''''Bumpy's Arcade Fantasy'''''. Loriciels wanted a 16-bit game so they handed it over to [[Infogrames]] who made ''Pop-up'' in 1991. The loading screen and graphics changed but the music sound effects and gameplay remained the same.{{cn|date=April 2017}} ==Gameplay== The player controls a ball, trying to get it to the exit by bouncing it off walls and various types of platforms. While most platforms are perfectly harmless, some have additional qualities, such as being destructible, thereby granting access to other parts of the screen. Some platforms are on fire, which will turn out lethal unless the player has picked up a water droplet in advance. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1989 video games]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum games]] [[Category:Amstrad CPC games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]]

{{Infobox company |name = Cosmote TV |logo = CosmoteTV Logo.png |caption = |type = Private (subsidiary of [[OTE]]) |industry = [[Telecommunications]] |genre = |foundation = September 2008 |dissolved = |location = |location_city = [[Athens]] |area_served = [[Greece]] |key_people = |products = [[IPTV]], [[Direct-broadcast satellite]], [[HbbTV]] |services = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |owner = [[OTE]] |num_employees = |parent = [[OTE]] |divisions = |subsid = |location_country = [[Greece]] |origins = |homepage = [https://www.cosmote.gr/cosmotetv Official Site] }} '''Cosmote TV''' is the corporate name for two [[pay television]] services in [[Greece]], owned by Greek [[telecommunication]] operator [[OTE]]. The two services are as follows:
*'''Cosmote TV via Broadband''' - [[IPTV]] service *'''Cosmote TV via Satellite''' - [[Direct-broadcast satellite|satellite]] television service
Cosmote TV Satellite broadcasts on Ku band from Eutelsat's [[Eurobird 9A]] at 9.0°E featuring DVB-S2 -8PSK/MPEG-4 technology. In June 2012 OTE TV had 76,345 subscribers. In July 2017, after more than 5 years of operation, it was announced that the (now) Cosmote TV package has reached 510,000 subscribers.
==History== In 2009, Greek Telecommunications giant OTE launched an IPTV service called '''Conn-x-TV'''. It was initially available in [[Athens]], [[Thessaloniki]], Patras, Larisa & Iraklion, it is available in most of [[Greece]].
In October 2011, ''Conn-x TV'' was re-branded as ''OTE TV via Conn-x''. At the same time, OTE launched their long anticipated satellite service known as ''OTE TV via Satellite''. Both services operate under the ''OTE TV'' brand and contain the same logo.
In March 2012 OTE TV had 63,497 subscribers. By the end of June 2012, reports say that the subscribers of OTE TV, both satellite and IP customers, had reached a total of 76,345. In November 2013, OTE TV reached 230,000 subscribers, most of them using the satellite service. In August 2014, the number of OTE TV subscribers surpassed 300,000 customers.
By the end of June 2015 OTE TV had 377,548 subscribers, while in June 2016 the platform had 458,920 subscribers (21.6% rise).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaltvinfo.gr/news/media-news/item/18027-thilia-sti-syndromitiki-tileorasi-i-kyvernitiki-forologisi|title=Θηλιά στη συνδρομητική τηλεόραση η κυβερνητική φορολόγηση|date=5 Σεπτεμβρίου 2016|website=digitaltvinfo}}</ref>
In January 2016, OTE TV announced the creation of OTE History, Greece's first local documentary channel, exclusively focused to Greek history, culture, and civilisation. The channel broadcasts documentaries licensed by Greece's most acclaimed documentary producers and global distribution companies as well as its own original productions. CEO of OTE Group Michael Tsamaz said in a press conference held for the presentation of the channel prior to launch: "OTE HISTORY is an important project for OTE, an organisation closely tied to the modern Greek history, with special cultural role and responsibility. With documentaries and high-quality shows with high aesthetic standards on the history, the culture, the people and the traditions of our country, this channel can be a new spot of entertainment and education for viewers. OTE HISTORY was created with a lot of effort, vision and respect for the content and its audience. It is our legacy to future generations".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cosmote.gr/fixed/en/corporate/media-center/news/details/-/asset_publisher/wpF6f9kWWozI/content/ote-history-%CF%84%CE%BF-%CF%80%CF%81%CF%89%CF%84%CE%BF-%CE%BA%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BB%CE%B9-%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%BF%CE%BA%CE%B9%CE%BC%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B5%CF%81-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD-%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%B4%CE%B1=|title= OTE HISTORY: The first documentary channel for Greece |date=20 Ιανουαρίου 2016|website=Cosmote}}</ref>
In August 2016 the OTE TV platform surpassed Nova Greece's subscribers reaching 462,000 customers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.gr/money/epixeiriseis/story/45255/h-forologia-frenare-tin-agora-syndromitikis-tileorasis|title=Η φορολογία "φρέναρε" την αγορά συνδρομητικής τηλεόρασης|date=6 Σεπτεμβρίου 2016|website=Cnn Greece}}</ref>
In November 2016 ''OTE TV'' was re-branded as ''Cosmote TV'' and its respective branded channels as Cosmote Cinema, Cosmote Sports, and Cosmote History. Moreover, as of November 2016, Cosmote TV has agreements with three of the six major studios, [[Walt Disney Pictures]], [[Paramount Pictures]] and [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]].
In January 2017 Cosmote TV reached 500,000 subscribers.
In July 2017 it was referred that Cosmote TV had reached 510,000 subscribers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sport24.gr/Columns/panos-voglis/h-ert-sthrigma-ths-kentrikhs-diaxeirishs.4758743.html|title=Η ΕΡΤ στήριγμα της κεντρικής διαχείρισης|date=10 Ιουλίου 2017|website=Cnn Greece}}</ref>
In 2017, Cosmote TV did not renew its co-operation with [[Discovery Communications]] as discussions between the two parties have not led to a mutually acceptable agreement. Therefore the following 8 channels: [[Discovery Channel Europe|Discovery Channel]], [[Discovery HD Showcase]], [[Discovery Science (European TV channel)|Discovery Science]], [[Investigation Discovery (Europe)|Investigation Discovery]], [[Animal Planet (Europe)|Animal Planet]], [[Eurosport 1]], [[Eurosport 2]] and [[TLC (TV network)|TLC]] will be replaced by [[BBC Earth (TV channel)|BBC Earth]], [[Crime & Investigation Network (Europe)|Crime & Investigation Network]], [[CBS Reality]], [[Fine Living (Europe)|Fine Living]], [[Food Network]], [[Fox Sports]], [[Nautical Channel]], [[Outdoor Channel]], [[Viasat Explore]] and [[Viasat Nature]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dziadul|first1=Chris|title=OTE’s Cosmote to drop Discovery channels|url=https://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2017/09/06/otes-cosmote-to-drop-discovery-channels/|accessdate=28 September 2017|publisher=broadbandtvnews.com|date=6 September 2017}}</ref>
